headline: Is Berkshire Hathaway Attractively Priced After Portfolio Moves And Record Cash Build?
summary: If you are wondering whether Berkshire Hathaway is still a smart buy at around $506 a share, you are not alone. It is the right question to be asking before you put fresh money to work. Despite a modest 0.4% slip over the last week, the stock is still up 6.1% over the past month, 12.3% year to date and 122.0% over five years, which indicates that the long-term story has been very rewarding for patient shareholders. Recent headlines have focused on Warren Buffett and the Berkshire team...

headline: 1 Small-Cap Stock with Competitive Advantages and 2 Facing Headwinds
summary: Small-cap stocks can be incredibly lucrative investments because their lack of analyst coverage leads to frequent mispricings. However, these businesses (and their stock prices) often stay small because their subscale operations make it harder to expand their competitive moats.

headline: Digital Check Certifies TellerScan®, CheXpress® Scanners with macOS 26
summary: NORTHBROOK, Ill., Dec. 03, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Digital Check Corp. has announced native support for macOS 26 “Tahoe” across its current TellerScan and CheXpress scanner families. The certification applies to Digital Check’s new TellerScan TS250 and CheXpress CX35 check scanner models, as well as to existing TS240 and CX30 devices, that use the latest version of the Digital Check API (DCC API). headline: FDA scrutiny of WHOOP signals challenges for niche wearable device makers
summary: Niche fitness-tracking firms such as WHOOP are coming under increased regulatory scrutiny as technological advances blur the lines between wearable and medical devices, exposing them to higher compliance costs ​and hampering their competitive advantage.  Although the U.S. Food and Drug Administration regulates certain health-focused tools in wearable devices such as smartwatches, many ‌companies have until now used a "regulatory gray zone" to bundle apps such as blood pressure monitors under advanced wellness features, without formal approvals.  However, the regulator has started to crack the ‌whip by making it clear that features such as blood pressure monitoring may be used by consumers to manage underlying health conditions and therefore would need its approval.

content.title: FDA scrutiny of WHOOP signals challenges for niche wearable device makers
content.summary: Niche fitness-tracking firms such as WHOOP are coming under increased regulatory scrutiny as technological advances blur the lines between wearable and medical devices, exposing them to higher compliance costs ​and hampering their competitive advantage.  Although the U.S. Food and Drug Administration regulates certain health-focused tools in wearable devices such as smartwatches, many ‌companies have until now used a "regulatory gray zone" to bundle apps such as blood pressure monitors under advanced wellness features, without formal approvals.  However, the regulator has started to crack the ‌whip by making it clear that features such as blood pressure monitoring may be used by consumers to manage underlying health conditions and therefore would need its approval.

thumbnail.caption: Signage is seen outside of FDA headquarters in White Oak, Maryland

headline: Trump admin. 'acting with urgency' with xLight stake: Pat Gelsinger
summary: The Trump administration will be taking an equity stake in semiconductor manufacturer startup xLight with a $150 million investment. xLight executive chair Pat Gelsinger sits down with Yahoo Finance executive editor Brian Sozzi to discuss xLight's chip technology, domestic chip production, the US Department of Commerce's investment, and his perspective on the AI ecosystem as OpenAI (OPAI.PVT) issues a "code red" over tightening competition and Alphabet's (GOOG, GOOGL) new spot as a top AI contender. Gelsinger is also the general partner of Playground Global and was the CEO of Intel (INTC) from 2021 until December 2024. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

content.title: Trump admin. 'acting with urgency' with xLight stake: Pat Gelsinger
content.description:
The Trump administration will be taking an equity stake in semiconductor manufacturer startup xLight with a $150 million investment.

xLight executive chair Pat Gelsinger sits down with Yahoo Finance executive editor Brian Sozzi to discuss xLight's chip technology, domestic chip production, the US Department of Commerce's investment, and his perspective on the AI ecosystem as OpenAI (OPAI.PVT) issues a "code red" over tightening competition and Alphabet's (GOOG, GOOGL) new spot as a top AI contender.

Gelsinger is also the general partner of Playground Global and was the CEO of Intel (INTC) from 2021 until December 2024.

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.
content.summary: The Trump administration will be taking an equity stake in semiconductor manufacturer startup xLight with a $150 million investment. xLight executive chair Pat Gelsinger sits down with Yahoo Finance executive editor Brian Sozzi to discuss xLight's chip technology, domestic chip production, the US Department of Commerce's investment, and his perspective on the AI ecosystem as OpenAI (OPAI.PVT) issues a "code red" over tightening competition and Alphabet's (GOOG, GOOGL) new spot as a top AI contender. Gelsinger is also the general partner of Playground Global and was the CEO of Intel (INTC) from 2021 until December 2024.
